content.description: Testosterone Alfresco follows a steep prow with fun moves on big holds.  It shares the same start as Sleeping Thunder but veers left after about 20'.  A great warm-up for some of the harder steeper routes on the wall.
content.protection: 10 or 11 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: Farthest route to the left on the main Cowboy Poetry wall.  Shares the same start as Sleeping Thunder.

content.description:
Super fun with huge juggy pockets on vertical to slightly overhanging stone.   The stone is completely bulletproof white limestone, and the setting is as pretty as you could hope for.

Lots of Sun!  Bring the sunscreen.

Pretty easy for the grade.  There is some trickiness down near the bottom but after that it is one jug after the other.   A genuinely classic 10- sport outing.

Another bouldery line at The Iris?  Who would have thunk it?  Climbs fun and mellowly up the face with a few intersting moves as the wall starts to kick back around the eighth bolt.  Then the thunder wakes.  Felt hard for the grade, but it is a good boulder problem and might be slightly height dependent.
content.location: Located on the left side of the wall, just before the 1st main break in the main face.  STh is just left of Cowboy Poetry.

content.description:
Excellent line with a burly distinct crux.

Start out in the seam and then move right on a slab.  The climbing up to the 4th bolt is probably easy 5.10.

Once you are done with this part, this leaves you under an overhanging bulge with a no-hands rest.

Then you do a 4 or 5 move sequence through a cruxy small pocket to a deep pocket.   From there it is a cakewalk to the anchors.

Not a one-move-wonder, but the sequence through the crux (8 feet) is definitely the main attraction - the rest of the route is fairly easy
content.location:
The trail deposits you at the crag right at a pine tree.  Right of the pine tree is

(1)  Princess and the Playmate (10b)

(2)  an 11a that starts in a seam then goes left

(3) Slapping Leather, which starts in the same seam (but has its own bolts) and goes right

content.description: Start off with a couple easy slab moves and climb the blunt arête to the pocketed face.
content.protection: 6 Bolts to anchor \ Pig Tail lower off's
content.location: When the main trail reaches the Cowboy Poetry Wall, follow trail to the right for approx. 150'

content.description:
A nice line.  While not as good as "Take your hat off...", it is probably a tad harder.  Also considerably more sharp.

Starts off with a cruxy thin section that was really tough for a 5'2" climber (my wife).   Then it becomes more reasonable for the vertically challenged, but stays pretty continuous.

One other oddity - there is no Cowboy theme detectable in the name.
content.location: The trail brings you out at a prominent pine tree in the middle of the crag.   This route starts just right of the pine tree.

content.description: Start just left of the shallow corner (sapling pine) and a steep wall. A couple easy moves off the ground lead to more difficult technical moves on edges, side-pulls under-clings and pockets. The route may seem easier if you are tall. The route is well protected and would make a great choice for anyone wishing to tick a 1st lead in its grade.
content.location: 15 feet right of "Sidewinder", starts just to climbers left of a Pine tree.

content.description: Hard right off the ground, with the crux and a great move to the 2nd bolt. Don't mess up the clip. A bit more difficulty at the 4th? bolt and it backs off to the top.
content.location: Right side of Cowboy Poetry Wall, behind a large pine tree.

content.description: Fun pocket-pulling on vertical face to start, followed by a series of bulges.  Different style moves required to pull through each of three bulges, followed by the 11 crux just before the chains.
content.location: This is the second climb from the left on the Cowboy Poetry Wall.  From the clean face where the trail leads you to the wall, walk left about 20 feet.  This climb is immediately left of a large chimney.

content.description: Starts just left of small pine and blunt arête, ("Burnin' Daylight")Fun moves on easy terrain! Loads of pockets and features on a low angled slab make this a perfect route to learn to lead on.
content.protection: 5 bolts to anchors \ Pig Tail lower-off's
content.location: 150 feet to the right of "Sidewinder", the cliff band dwindles into a tree filled gulley on left. A small wall rises straight ahead on the trail, "Ella's Pony Ride" is the 1st route on the left side of this wall.

climbs.name: Drove Hard and Put Up Quick

content.description: Start just right of a pine tree, Use crack and pockets to pull over bulge to some tricky moves on a clean face.
content.protection: 5 bolts to anchors \ Pig Tail lower-off's

content.description:
PLEASE DO NOT CLIMB THIS ROUTE UNTIL AFTER July 31st, 2020: Raptors are nesting in the area and Disturbance could result in abandonment of their nest resulting in egg or chick loss and increase the chance of predation. This is not only a climber safety issue but an important measure to protect the nesting birds. Thanks for your cooperation!”

Bolted, chopped, re-bolted!  Starts with technical slab on speckled black rock, moving up an intermittent seam feature. Better pockets up high.  From the indentation at the horizontal seam, prepare for the bulge above. Easier than it looks!  The vertical crack right of the two black streaks makes for a sharp jam, but plenty of holds to avoid this.  Single set of anchors above the bulge (formerly below).
content.location: Immediately right of Buffalo Soldier, beginning just left of a juniper tree that grows against the wall.

content.description:
Beautiful line that can be done to the first anchor at 11b or all the way to the top at 12b.

Overhangs slightly and climbs stellar pockets.

The most distinguising feature is an obvious 6 foot long edge that angles from low left to upper right towards the middle of the route.  The edge is all chalked up and from below you fully expect a jug when you get there.   However, the edge is actually some sloper action!  Fun!
content.protection: 6-8 bolts to the first anchor, 2 more bolts to the second anchor. First anchor has Clip-n-Lowers, second anchor only has rap rings
content.location: On the left side of the wall.  Look for a route with the aforementioned diagonal edge in it.  You can't miss it.

content.description: Another high quality Wild Iris 5.10, Latex offers great pocket pulling in a beautiful setting.  The crux comes right away, with some long moves from good 2-finger pockets.  Above a few long reaches between jugs leads to a sea of nice pockets on a nearly-vertical wall.
content.location: On the far left end of the CP wall, climbing the left, shorter route in a recessed panel that hosts two routes.  Begins immediately right of a shallow right-facing dihedral.

content.description: This route used to be an easier variation to Cowboy Poetry that bailed left to avoid the high roof.  Unfortunately some mentally ill person ( probably the notorious crag menace Alf) chopped the bolts.  Fortunately there is a lowering station just below the roof, so its still possible to climb the 5.11 section of Cowboy Poetry and skip the roof.
content.location: What remains is the vertical portion of Cowboy Poetry, now ending just below the big roof.

content.description: Start between 2 pine trees. Climb fun moves up a blunt arête.
content.protection: 5 bolts to anchors \ Pig Tail lower-off's

content.description:
Every bit as good as its more esteemed neighbor to the left, Buffalo Soldier is an excellent moderate pocket-pulling masterpiece. This long & sustained line is the perfect warmup route, and a worthy objective in its own right.

Begin up steeper rock just below the thin detached flake. A few thin moves work up to the flake, where the holds increase in size. The angle kicks back a bit and excellent pockets begin to appear just where you need them as you cruise up the excellent slab. This line finishes at an anchor atop the slab, but there is a bolted extension (Charlie Drew That Sinnin' Bull, 5.12c)that tackles the looming roof.
content.location: In the center of the Cowboy Poetry Wall, immediately right of "Take Your Hat Off Boy".  This line can be identified by a two-foot wide flake about 10' above the ground.

content.description:
PLEASE DO NOT CLIMB THIS ROUTE OR IT"S EXTENSION UNTIL AFTER July 31st, 2020: Raptors are nesting in the area and Disturbance could result in abandonment of their nest resulting in egg or chick loss and increase the chance of predation. This is not only a climber safety issue but an important measure to protect the nesting birds. Thanks for your cooperation!”

Thin tedious climbing right off the ground on poor holds marks the first 10 feet of this route and the crux. The remainder of the climbing is straight forward all the way to the anchor.
content.protection: 5 bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: Third route to the right of Buffalo Soldier.  Starts just left of a small pine tree.

content.description: Several hundred feet down and right of the preceding routes, and across a tree gully to a lower cliff band.   This route follows the arete at the left end of the cliff band.
